column4: ﻿Dunas: your problem lies in line 56 of the nvidia-xconfig generated conf. It seems to believe your board is vesa-compatible, not nvidia. Is your card integrated or dedicated, and what system is it on?

﻿barjoman: by default, the first user you create for the system has sudo privs, so I'm not sure what happened there. You could try an Ubuntu live cd, that would let you mount the system and modify your sudoers file, albeit uncleanly
good luck barjoman
it's a simple integrated nvidia chipset
yes, i know
there's a specific set of motherboards with integrated nvidia chips in the same family as his that have a long-standing problem, I want to see if that is the case here
then ask for the lspci output
doesn't give me the motherboard model 70% of the time
lspci never does. but usually lshw does
but since it's an acer you woN't get the mobo model anyways. it's a Acer OEM
a GF7100 is never a nf4
i meant using hardware querying period, sorry I wasn't more specific
you're sure that his motherboard doesn't use the n4 then?
I asked you to use lspci then which you dismissed for no good reason. if it's nf4, lspci will tell you. BUT: no one sells current PCs with nf4 since a few years now
so yes, it's not a NF4 with a E2160 in it...

I didn't dismiss lspci outright, I only said it wasn't likely to give the info needed. I didn't know how recent his computer was, nor do I have an intimate enough knowledge of nvidia cards to know offhand which are in which set. Thanks for the info :)
it ALWAYS gives the chipset info. ALWAYS
is his graphics chipset not able to use nvidia-glx at all then?
because that would be odd
it is. but we need the output from a testrun where he uses nvidia, not VESA. can't diagnose nvidia problems when the VESA driver is used, can we?
of course :) but i thought it was odd that nvidia-xconfig was identifying the board as vesa
thanks for the infos!
